head.title: Simultaneous Dechlorination and Advanced Oxidation Using Electrically Conductive Carbon Nanotube Membranes | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Simultaneous Dechlorination and Advanced Oxidation Using Electrically Conductive Carbon Nanotube Membranes

Electrically conductive membranes have shown significant promise in combining conventional separations with in situ contaminant oxidation, but little has been done to consider chlorine removal. This study demonstrates the simultaneous chlorine removal and oxidation of organic compounds during filtration using an electrochemically assisted electrically conductive carbon nanotube (CNT) membrane. As much as 80% of chlorine was removed in the feed by CNT membranes at the initial phase of continuous filtration. The efficacy of these CNT membranes toward chlorine removal was dependent on the mass of CNTs within the membranes and the applied pressure to the membranes, indicating the central role of available CNT active sites and sufficient reaction time. Furthermore, the removal mechanism of chlorine by CNTs was revealed by studying the degradation of benzoic acid and cyclic voltammetry on the membrane surface. Reactive oxidants were generated by the reductive decomposition of chlorine through the catalytic interaction with CNTs. Subsequently, electrical potentials were applied to the CNT membrane surfaces during the filtration of chlorinated feed waters. The simultaneous decomposition of chlorine and oxidation of benzoic acid were significantly enhanced by applying a cathodic current to CNT membranes enabling continuous dechlorination. The cathodic current applied to CNT membranes is believed to regenerate CNT membranes by providing electrons for the reductive decomposition of chlorine. In situ chemical-free dechlorination coupled with membrane filtration offers great opportunity to reducing the environmental impact of desalination, while maximizing the lifetime of reverse osmosis membranes and demonstrating greener approaches available to industrial water treatment.

div.p: Electrically conductive membranes have shown significant promise in combining conventional separations with in situ contaminant oxidation, but little has been done to consider chlorine removal. This study demonstrates the simultaneous chlorine removal and oxidation of organic compounds during filtration using an electrochemically assisted electrically conductive carbon nanotube (CNT) membrane. As much as 80% of chlorine was removed in the feed by CNT membranes at the initial phase of continuous filtration. The efficacy of these CNT membranes toward chlorine removal was dependent on the mass of CNTs within the membranes and the applied pressure to the membranes, indicating the central role of available CNT active sites and sufficient reaction time. Furthermore, the removal mechanism of chlorine by CNTs was revealed by studying the degradation of benzoic acid and cyclic voltammetry on the membrane surface. Reactive oxidants were generated by the reductive decomposition of chlorine through the catalytic interaction with CNTs. Subsequently, electrical potentials were applied to the CNT membrane surfaces during the filtration of chlorinated feed waters. The simultaneous decomposition of chlorine and oxidation of benzoic acid were significantly enhanced by applying a cathodic current to CNT membranes enabling continuous dechlorination. The cathodic current applied to CNT membranes is believed to regenerate CNT membranes by providing electrons for the reductive decomposition of chlorine. In situ chemical-free dechlorination coupled with membrane filtration offers great opportunity to reducing the environmental impact of desalination, while maximizing the lifetime of reverse osmosis membranes and demonstrating greener approaches available to industrial water treatment.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Polyamide reverse osmosis (RO) membranes are the most commonly used membranes for desalination and potable water reuse processes. However, the performance of these membranes is significantly hindered by surface biofouling.
(1,2)
To mitigate biofouling of RO membranes, large volumes of chlorine are often used as disinfectants in the pretreatment step.
(3,4)
However, polyamide RO membranes are susceptible to oxidative degradation by free chlorine. RO membrane manufacturers usually suggest that the concentration of free chlorine in feed waters should be less than 0.1 mg/L. As such, chlorine must be quenched before treated water comes into contact with RO membranes to prevent performance deterioration and permanent oxidative damage of the RO membrane polyamide active layers.
(5−7)
Finally, re-chlorination of permeate waters is performed for distribution in water mains. Chemical treatment in membrane process trains is wasteful and costly.

In current desalination processes, dechlorination and potable reuse is achieved by the addition of neutralizing solutions (such as sodium metabisulfite (Na
2
S
2
O
5
) and sodium bisulfite (2NaHSO
3
)).
(8,9)
Although the usage of these chemical reagents is an effective method to achieve dechlorination, it has been reported to result in severe biofouling by promoting bacterial growth.
(10,11)
Further, this additional processing step in the process train increases a RO plant’s OPEX. Alternative disinfectants using nonoxidizing biocides have been investigated, but these methods have been shown to be effective for only a narrow range of microorganism strains, and they are mostly ineffective for a broad range of microorganisms found in surface water and wastewaters.
(12−14)
There has been a wide range of material studies to improve the chlorine resistance of polyamide membranes, which include modification of the polyamide polymer structure, coating of protective layers, and incorporation of nanomaterials (carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene oxide) into polyamide.
(15−19)
However, these strategies generally cause undesirable reduction of the RO membrane permeate flux. Additionally, while most of these studies have been demonstrated at the laboratory scale, scale-up of these modified polyamide RO membranes, and the associated economic feasibility, remains uncertain. As such, chlorination is still the most common way for upstream disinfection due to its effectiveness, facile use, and low cost despite the need for downstream dechlorination and subsequent re-chlorination after RO.

Decomposition of chlorine can be induced on activated carbon and through exposure to hydrogen peroxide, metal catalysts (such as nickel, cobalt, iron, and copper), UV irradiation, and other reducing reagents.
(20−25)
Dechlorination strategies using UV irradiation and iron catalysts can generate reactive oxidants through the chemical activation of chlorine (
reactions 1
and
2
for UV/chlorine and Fe/chlorine, respectively).
(21,22,24)
(1)
(2)

In the past two decades, CNTs have been recognized as excellent carbocatalysts to activate persulfates for the catalytic oxidation of organic compounds.
(26,27)
Several studies have demonstrated the superior performance of CNTs, over metal oxides and activated carbon, for phenolic compound degradation by promoting the conversion of persulfates into sulfate radical anions (SO
4
•–
).
(25,26)
CNTs were also shown to improve
•
OH formation during ozonation.
(28)
Similarly, we hypothesized that the combination of CNTs with chlorine may generate reactive oxidants during chlorine decomposition.

Here we attempted to apply CNTs in combination with chlorine in a hybrid filter platform for simultaneous dechlorination and advanced oxidation. The application of CNT membranes has clear advantages over the conventional dechlorination method using reducing reagents. First, CNT membranes could decompose chlorine without the use of costly chemicals, providing a nonchemical dechlorination method. Second, the additional dechlorination unit operation before the RO stage can be eliminated by replacing current membranes used in pretreatment with CNT-based membranes (either as a microfiltration (MF) or ultrafiltration (UF) membrane), providing lower operational costs and reduced environmental impacts. Lastly, the activation of chlorine by CNT membranes could produce a high-quality pretreated water (MF/UF filtrate) by generating reactive species at the membrane surface that can degrade organic contaminants in feed waters as well as mitigating organic fouling.
(29)
To date, electrically conductive membranes that can catalytically achieve in situ dechlorination have not been studied. This study demonstrates this chemical-free technique and will inspire further development in similar green dechlorination processes.

The objective of this study was to examine and compare the decomposition of chlorine by CNT membranes and electrochemically assisted CNT membranes. Furthermore, for the first time, we experimentally elucidated the decomposition mechanism of chlorine on the CNT surfaces. In addition, we investigated the potential production of reactive oxidants by the CNT/chlorine system through the use of probe compounds and quantified the oxidation of model organic compounds.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
All chemicals were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Sodium hypochlorite solution (NaOCl, 10–15% active chlorine), benzoic acid (BA; C
7
H
6
O
2
), nitrobenzene (C
6
H
5
NO
2
), methanol (CH
3
OH), sodium phosphate monobasic (NaH
2
PO
4
), and sodium phosphate dibasic (Na
2
HPO
4
) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Co. (USA). Acetonitrile (CH
3
CN) and sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS, C
12
H
25
NaO
4
S) were purchased from J.T. Baker (USA) and Anachemia (Canada), respectively. CNTs (carboxylated single-walled–double walled CNTs (COOH-SW/DW CNT)) were obtained from Cheaptubes Inc. (USA). All stock and buffer solutions were prepared in 18 MΩ·cm Milli-Q water from a Millipore system.

CNT membranes were prepared based on a previously described process with a slight modification.
(30)
Briefly, a suspension containing 0.04 wt % CNT powder and 0.06 wt % SDS was prepared in deionized (DI) water and stirred for 30 min. This suspension was sonicated with a sonication probe (Q500 sonicator, Qsonica, LLC., USA) for 30 min, interspersed by 2 s pulses. Different amounts of CNT suspensions were pressure-deposited onto the polyethersulfone (PES) support membrane (0.03 μm, 47 mm; Sterlitech, USA), with the final contents of 3, 6, 9, and 18 mg CNT per membrane and washed several times with DI water after deposition. The formed membranes were dried at 100 °C for 1 h and stored in deionized water at 4 °C until used.

div.h3: 2.3. Experimental Setup and Procedure of Batch and Filtration Experiments
div.div:
For batch experiments using CNT powder, a 125 mL Pyrex flask was used and opened to the atmosphere at room temperature (22 ± 2 °C). The reaction was initiated by adding an aliquot of a freshly prepared stock solution of chlorine to a CNT-dispersed solution. Reaction samples were withdrawn using a 10 mL syringe at predetermined time intervals, and they were immediately filtered through a 0.2 μm polyvinylidene fluoride syringe filter (Advantec Co., USA) for further analysis. The initial pH of the solutions was adjusted with 0.1 N NaOH and 0.1 N H
2
SO
4
after adding chlorine, and the pH variations during the reaction were less than 0.2 units. Flow-through experiments using CNT membranes were performed using a steel dead-end filtration cell (Sterlitech, USA) with an effective membrane area of 14.6 cm
2
. Prior to the chlorine removal experiments, each membrane was pressurized with DI water at 100 psi for about 2 h to avoid the compaction effect of the membrane. Then, the cell with the feed water containing 1 mg/L chlorine as Cl
2
was pressurized at different pressure ranges from 10 to 100 psi using N
2
gas, and the filtrate was instantaneously collected for the measurements of chlorine decomposition at predetermined time intervals.

div.h3: 2.4. Experimental Setup of the Electrochemical Reactor and Procedure
div.div:
Electrochemical experiments in batch mode were carried out in an open and single-compartment cell. CNT membranes were used as the cathode with an effective area of 8.62 cm
2
(Figure S1a in the
Supporting Information
). Graphite and Ag/AgCl electrode were employed as the counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively. The distance between the cathode and anode was 2 cm, and 100 mM phosphate buffer was used as the supporting electrolyte. During the electrochemically assisted experiment, the constant current was applied by a Multi Autolab M204 potentiostat/galvanostat (Metrohm, Switzerland). The reaction samples were withdrawn at predetermined time intervals and analyzed to determine the concentration of chlorine.

Electrochemical experiments in flow-through mode were performed using a custom-built, electrochemical dead-end filtration unit with a capacity of 10 mL (Figure S1b in the
Supporting Information
). This filtration cell has an effective membrane area of 2.69 cm
2
. In these experiments, the CNT membrane and graphite were used as the cathode and anode, respectively. The distance between the two electrodes was 5 mm, and 100 mM phosphate buffer was used as a background electrolyte. The cell was pressurized at 15 psi (1.0 bar) using N
2
gas. Filtration was carried out, while electrolysis occurred controlled by the potentiostat. The filtrate was collected for further analysis and weighed after each filtration interval. All experiments were conducted without the circulation of the feed solution.

BA and 4-hydroxybenzoic acid (4-HBA; i.e., the oxidation product of BA) were analyzed using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC; Waters HPLC/UV–vis detector, Waters, Inc., USA), with the UV absorbance detection at 272 nm. Separation was performed on an Acclaim 120 C18 column (2.1 mm × 150 mm, 5 μm; Thermo scientific, Inc., USA). A mixture of 10 mM nitric acid/acetonitrile (65%/35% and 80%/20% (v/v) for BA and 4-HBA, respectively) was used as the mobile phase at a 0.15 mL min
–1
flow rate.

Chlorine stock solution (100 mg/L as Cl
2
) was freshly prepared using sodium hypochlorite solution (NaOCl, 10–15% active chlorine). Stock solutions of chlorine were standardized spectrophotometrically based on their molar absorption coefficient: ε = 350 M
–1
cm
–1
at 292 nm for OCl
–
,
(31)
and free chlorine was determined by Standard Method 4500-Cl.
(32)

Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was carried out using the same three-electrode cell setup for all electrochemical experiments in batch mode as described above. CV was performed in the voltage range of 0–0.7 V (vs Ag/AgCl) at a scan rate of 5 mV/s. 1 M phosphate buffer was used as the supporting electrolyte, and the solution was saturated with nitrogen for 30 min prior to use for all experiments.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.p:
Figure 1. Chlorine removal by CNT membrane in a flow-through filtration system (initial chlorine = 1 ppm as Cl
2
; feed pH = 6.0; applied pressure = 10 psi; CNT = 9 mg; permeate flux = 316 L/m
2
/h; and error bars represent the standard deviations from at least two experimental results).

div.h3: 3.2. Effect of Loaded CNT Mass and Applied Pressure on Chlorine Removal
div.div:
Both the CNT loading on coated membranes and the applied pressure for filtration were optimized for chlorine removal efficiency using single-pass flow-through filtration experiments. The profile of chlorine removal was obtained as a function of filtrate volume for different masses of CNTs (3, 6, 9, and 18 mg) and applied pressures (10 psi (69 kPa), 30 psi (207 kPa), and 50 psi (345 kPa)) (Figure S3 in the
Supporting Information
). In general, a linear decrease in chlorine removal was observed over the first 10 mL of filtered water. The rate of chlorine removal decreased until a steady state was achieved for continued chlorinated water flux from 10 to 200 mL. It is noteworthy that the relative chlorine concentrations at steady state (i.e., the relative concentration of chlorine in the permeate as compared to that in the feed at 200 mL) never reached complete saturation (i.e., the permeate always contained less chlorine than the feed) for all the tested conditions. This result implies that chlorine adsorption to CNTs was not the only removal mechanism but that catalytic decomposition also occurred. Simple adsorption would eventually lead to complete saturation (i.e., relative chlorine concentration ≈ 1) of CNT membranes. Detailed experiments to probe the mechanism of catalytic decomposition of chlorine by CNTs will be further discussed in
Section 3.3
.

Chlorine removal efficiency (at filtrate volume 200 mL) and permeate flux are presented in
Figure
2
a as a function of CNT coating mass, evaluated at a constant applied pressure (10 psi). Membranes containing low amounts of CNTs were less effective in chlorine removal than membranes with higher amounts of CNTs, demonstrating that the available CNT surface area plays a key role in chlorine removal during filtration. Chlorine removal efficiencies were 11.4, 29.6, 43.8, and 44.1% for 3, 6, 9, and 18 mg CNT membranes, respectively (
Figure
2
a). However, no significant enhancement in chlorine removal was measured by doubling the CNT mass from 9 to 18 mg CNTs. We hypothesize that CNT aggregation may have contributed to the lack of enhanced chlorine removal at the highest CNT mass loading, as aggregation can limit the total available surface area.

div.p:
Figure 2. Observed rate constants for chlorine saturation on CNT membranes by different masses of CNT loading (a) and applied pressures (b) in flow-through filtration [initial chlorine = 1 ppm as Cl
2
; (a) applied pressure = 10 psi; filtrate volume 200 mL; (b) CNT mass loading = 9 mg CNT; error bars represent the standard deviations from at least two experimental results].

div.div:
Permeate flux demonstrated the expected opposite trend; permeate flux constantly decreased with increasing mass of CNTs on membranes. However, membranes containing 18 mg CNTs had similar permeate flux (310 L/m
2
/h) as compared to 9 mg CNT membranes (316 L/m
2
/h). The correlation between permeate fluxes and chlorine removal demonstrates that a higher residence time leads to greater chlorine removal, that is, lower transmembrane flux provides more time for chlorine adsorption on CNTs. The decrease in the permeate flux with increasing CNT mass on membranes could be attributed to the decreased porosity of membranes as more CNTs form thicker layers on the support membranes, as reported in a previous study.
(30)
As there was no advantage to using 18 mg membranes, all subsequent experiments were performed using membranes fabricated with 9 mg CNTs.

Subsequently, we investigated the chlorine removal efficiency and permeate flux of CNT membranes (at 200 mL filtrate volume) as a function of different applied pressures (10, 30, and 50 psi), as shown in
Figure
2
b. Increasing applied pressures led to a decrease in the chlorine removal efficiency (43.8, 32.9, and 18.3% for 10, 30, and 50 psi, respectively). When applied pressures increased from 10 to 50 psi, the permeate flux steadily increased from 316 to 2055 L/m
2
/h. Higher fluxes reduce the residence time of chlorine within the CNT membranes, leading to faster chlorine breakthrough, while lower fluxes provide sufficient residence time for interaction between chlorine and the active sites on CNT membranes. This observation further supports the importance of residence time for chlorine removal during chlorinated water filtration. Overall, these results indicate that the mass of CNTs, and thereby the total available surface area for chlorine removal, as well as the residence time of chlorine within the active sites of CNT membranes, are critical parameters for the removal of chlorine through CNT membranes.

div.h3: 3.3. Generation of Reactive Oxidants during the Decomposition of Chlorine by CNTs
div.div:
CNTs are known to be good adsorbents for many molecules in aqueous systems including chlorine, as experimentally demonstrated above. However, the chlorine removal mechanism by CNTs may additionally be caused by reductive decomposition of chlorine. Indeed, activated carbon, which also contains sp
2
-hybridized carbon structures similar to CNTs, has been demonstrated to reduce chlorine species via surface chemical reactions.
(33,34)
We hypothesized that CNTs could chemically decompose chlorine and, in so doing, could activate chlorine to generate reactive oxidants as byproducts in water. To quantify the production of reactive oxidants, we examined the oxidation and removal of BA in the presence of CNTs with and without chlorine (
Figure
3
). The oxidation of BA produces 4-HBA, which was distinguished from benzoic acid using HPLC/UV–vis measurements.

div.p:
Figure 3. Removal of BA (black, red, and blue symbols) by chlorine, CNT, and CNT/chlorine (CNT = 10 mg; initial chlorine = 100 ppm as Cl
2
; BA = 0.1 mM), with the corresponding formation of 4-HBA (green symbol) in the presence of CNT/chlorine; error bars represent the standard deviation from at least two experimental results.

div.div:
In the presence of chlorine alone, the concentration of BA did not change throughout a 4 h period. In contrast, in the presence of CNTs alone (without chlorine), the concentration of BA decreased by approximately 35% after 4 h, demonstrating the adsorption capacity of CNTs for BA. CNTs were saturated with BA after 2 h, such that the concentration of BA remained constant throughout the subsequent 2 h. In order to examine the synergistic effect of CNTs and chlorine, chlorine was added to the batch reactors after CNTs were saturated with BA (2 h exposure). At this point, CNT adsorption caused a decrease in the BA concentration by approximately 35%. After the chlorine addition to the saturated CNTs, a measurable and significant further degradation of BA was observed by the CNT/chlorine system, showing 1.5 times enhancement of the BA removal as compared to that of CNTs alone. In the CNT/chlorine system, the concentration of BA in the batch reactors decreased by a total of over 50%. To verify that the CNT/chlorine system was causing the degradation of BA rather than leading to enhanced adsorption, we measured the rate of formation of 4-HBA, a product of the hydroxylation of BA (
Figure
3
). 4-HBA formation increased with similar kinetics as BA degradation. Based on these results, it is clear that CNTs activate chlorine into a more reactive species that can oxidatively degrade organic compounds.

To probe further whether chlorine is activated by CNTs, the reaction mechanism between chlorine and CNTs was investigated by CV. CNTs were deposited onto a polymeric support membrane to synthesize CNT membranes that could be used as electrodes. CV curves were obtained with these CNT membranes as the working electrode while they were exposed to chlorine.
Figure
4
shows the CV curves scanned with different concentrations of chlorine (100, 500, and 1000 mg/L as Cl
2
). The CV curve for CNT membranes in the absence of chlorine exhibited a quasi-rectangular shape without any peaks, indicating the typical electric double-layer capacitance behavior of CNTs. The quasi-rectangular shape indicates both the reversibility of the electric double layer formed on the CNT membranes as well as the absence of any redox reactions. There was only a slight shift in the CV curve into cathodic currents in the presence of 100 mg/L chlorine as Cl
2
. Increasing the concentration of chlorine further caused the curves to shift significantly toward the cathodic current as well as to produce a strong asymmetric distortion in the shape. We also observed an increase in the cathodic currents with an increasing concentration of chlorine in linear sweep voltammograms (Figure S4 in the
Supporting Information
). A broad cathodic peak was observed in the presence of 1000 mg/L chlorine as Cl
2
, while no anodic peak was found under the reverse potential scan. The large shift toward cathodic currents demonstrates that a reduction reaction occurs at the CNT membrane electrode in the presence of chlorine. The asymmetry in the CV curves indicates that the electrochemical reduction of chlorine at the CNT membrane electrode is an irreversible process. Overall, the CV technique verified the reductive property of CNTs in the presence of chlorine. Similarly, carbon materials including CNTs have been reported to have reducing capability in several previous studies.
(35,36)
The indication from CV curves that chlorine is reduced in the presence of CNTs coupled with the observation that reduced chlorine can convert HBA to 4-HBA suggests that the CNT-catalyzed reductive reaction of chlorine could produce reactive oxidants. From the Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra (Figure S5 in
the Supporting Information
), it is observed that O–H stretching (3200–3500 cm
–1
) and C═O stretching (1630 cm
–1
) arising from quinone groups appeared in CNT membranes after the exposure to chlorine. These results further confirm that CNTs partially oxidize, while chlorine was reductively decomposed. We propose that CNTs act as catalysts for the activation of chlorine, following an analogous mechanism in the Fe/chlorine system.
(24)
As evidenced by the formation of 4-HBA,
•
OH is likely the responsible reactive oxidant species that caused the degradation of BA. However, it is possible that additional minor radical species may also be generated (i.e.,
•
OH vs Cl
•
comparing
reactions 3
and
4
, respectively) through the reductive conversion of HOCl by CNTs.
(3)
(4)

div.p:
Figure 4. Cyclic voltammograms obtained by the CNT membrane in the absence and presence of chlorine (initial chlorine = 100, 500, and 1000 mg/L as Cl
2
; CNTs = 9 mg; pH = 7.0 (1 M phosphate buffer); scan rate = 5 mV/s).

div.h3: 3.4. Enhanced Decomposition of Chlorine by Electrochemically Assisted CNT Membranes in Batch Mode
div.div:
The ability to decompose residual chlorine was decreased by the active site saturation of CNT membrane, as was observed from the single-pass flow-through experiment (
Figures
1
and S3 in the
Supporting Information
). CNT saturation is a significant obstacle for long-term continuous filtration applications. Based on the obtained results, the reductive reaction between chlorine and CNTs is believed to be the primary mechanism for the decomposition of chlorine. As such, we hypothesized that the ability of CNT membranes to remove chlorine through reductive decomposition could be continuously regenerated by using CNT membranes as cathodic electrodes, that is, providing electrons to CNT membranes for the continuous electrochemical reduction of chlorine. Cathodic decomposition of chlorine was monitored at different current densities in a batch mode using a CNT membrane as a working electrode (
Figure
5
a). In the absence of current on the CNT membrane, a slight chlorine removal (<20%) was observed over 30 min of reaction time. The degradation of chlorine was significantly accelerated by applying a potential to the CNT membrane. The decomposition of chlorine in the electrolyte was significantly enhanced with increasing current density, achieving 44 and 72% removal in 30 min for 5.8 and 9.3 A/m
2
, respectively. The adoption of these current densities corresponded to the average potential of −0.9 V versus Ag/AgCl and −1.2 V versus Ag/AgCl for 5.8 A/m
2
and 9.3 A/m
2
, respectively (Figure S6 in the
Supporting Information
). This enhanced chlorine degradation indicates that cathodic currents on CNT membranes can prompt the reduction of chlorine by regenerating CNT active sites. In contrast, other materials, such as Pt and graphite electrodes, were not effective in decomposing chlorine under identical current density conditions (
Figure
5
b,c). This significant electrocatalytic activity of CNTs for the reduction of chlorine could be the result of CNTs’ large basal/edge plane anisotropy and their semimetallic character, as well as chlorine’s high electrophilicity.
(36)
Research on developing CNT-based chlorine sensors further indicates the existence of a specific preferential interaction between CNTs and chlorine. CNTs have been demonstrated to be excellent electrochemical chlorine sensors as a result of their effective chlorine reduction as compared to that of graphite.
(37)
Our results show that this preferential interaction can be enhanced through the application of an external cathodic potential.

div.p:
Figure 5. Decomposition of chlorine by electrochemically assisted CNT membrane (a), Pt electrode (b), and graphite electrode (c) in batch reactors (initial chlorine = 2 ppm as Cl
2
; CNTs = 9 mg; phosphate buffer = 100 mM; error bars represent the standard deviation from at least two experimental results).

div.h3: 3.5. Enhanced Decomposition of Chlorine by Electrochemically Assisted CNT Membranes in Flow-Through Mode
div.div:
We further examined the regeneration capability of electrochemically assisted CNT membranes for chlorine removal in a single-pass flow-through mode under different current density conditions (
Figure
6
). In the absence of current, chlorine breakthrough increased throughout continuous filtration, suggesting that CNT active sites were consumed quickly as chlorine passed through the membrane. In contrast, electrochemically assisted CNT membranes exhibited continuous removal of chlorine throughout filtration, indicating the successful regeneration of active sites on CNT membranes by applying cathodic currents. As expected from the results in batch mode, the decomposition of chlorine was higher with a higher current density (chlorine removal efficiencies of 56 and 77% at a filtrate volume of 100 mL for 0.19 and 0.37 A/m
2
, respectively). The adoption of these current densities corresponded to the ranges of cell voltage 1.6–1.8 and 2.0–2.2 V for 0.19 and 0.37 A/m
2
, respectively. It is noteworthy that a much lower current density was required to achieve the same degree of chlorine removal in flow-through mode as compared to that in batch mode. This can be explained by the fact that the likelihood of contact between chlorine molecules and CNT active sites is considerably higher in flow-through mode than in batch mode. Unlike the behavior of CNT membranes without current, the concentration of chlorine in the filtrate at first increased and then gradually decreased at the given current densities (0.19 and 0.37 A/m
2
) as the filtration proceeded. This trend could be attributed to the combined effects of two factors: (1) decrease in chlorine removal by adsorption due to the repulsive electrostatic forces between the negatively charged membrane and chlorine molecules (OCl
–
) and (2) increase in chlorine removal through the oxidation reactions (
reactions 5
and
6
) with reactive species generated from
reactions 3
and
4
during the reductive conversion of HOCl by CNTs.
(21)
(5)
(6)

div.p:
Figure 6. Decomposition of chlorine by electrochemically assisted CNT membranes in batch mode (flow rate = 2 mL/min; initial chlorine = 2 ppm as Cl
2
; CNTs = 9 mg; phosphate buffer = 100 mM; error bars represent the standard deviations from at least two experimental results).

div.div:
Degradation of BA was also examined in flow-through mode using electrochemically assisted CNT membranes (
Figure
7
). Adsorptive removal of BA was approximately 20%, which occurred at the initial phase of filtration. Subsequent BA removal continually decreased during further continuous filtration. After the CNT membranes were fully saturated with adsorbed BA, the reaction on CNT membranes was initiated by applying current and through the addition of chlorine. There was no significant degradation of BA with either the application of current alone or with the addition of chlorine alone. This lack of significant BA removal indicated that neither the direct electrolysis of BA nor the production of reactive species under the given current conditions occurred. In contrast, substantial removal of BA (approximately 50%) was observed by the combination of chlorine with current, demonstrating the in situ catalytic oxidation of BA through the electrochemically assisted CNT activation of chlorine. The removal efficiency of BA was gradually enhanced as filtration proceeded, implying that the production of reactive species was increased. This result further supports our hypothesis that chlorine removal increased through oxidation reactions with reactive species over the course of filtration, as shown in
Figure
6
. Overall, our results indicated that applying cathodic currents can enhance the ability of CNT membranes to decompose chlorine as well as produce reactive oxidant species by regenerating CNT active sites on the surface of the CNT membranes.

div.p:
Figure 7. Removal of BA by the electrochemically assisted CNT membrane in the absence and presence of chlorine (flow rate = 2 mL/min; CNTs = 9 mg; initial chlorine = 10 ppm as Cl
2
; BA = 0.1 mM; phosphate buffer = 100 mM; error bars represent the standard deviations from at least two experimental results).

div.h3: 3.6. Effect of pH on the Decomposition of Chlorine by CNT Membranes
div.div:
The decomposition of chlorine using CNT membranes was investigated at different pHs (i.e., pH 4, 7, and 11) in a single-pass flow-through mode (
Figure
8
). At pH 4, chlorine is present in protonated form (HOCl). Deprotonation of chlorine occurs near pH 7.5 (p
K
a
for HOCl) and completely dissociates into anions (OCl
–
) at pH 11. Chlorine removal dramatically decreased with increasing pH, while chlorine removal was enhanced with decreasing pH both with and without the applied current (
Figure
8
a,b). This result indicates that the deprotonated form of chlorine (OCl
–
) is unfavorable for chlorine removal. This pH dependency in chlorine removal was also consistent with the results of the CNT/HOCl system tested in batch experiments (Figure S7a in the
Supporting Information
). An inhibitory effect at the alkaline environment is likely the result of electrostatic repulsion between the negatively charged carboxyl functional groups (−COO
–
) of CNT membranes and chlorine anions (OCl
–
). However, it appeared that the impact of pH was slightly suppressed by applying current (compare
Figure
8
a,b). Degradation of BA was also marginally inhibited as the solution pH increased, implying that the effective adsorption of chlorine to the active sites of CNT membranes is essential for the formation of reactive species as well as for chlorine removal (Figure S7b in the
Supporting Information
).

div.p:
Figure 8. Decomposition of chlorine by electrochemically assisted CNT membrane at current densities of 0 (a) and 0.37 A/m
2
(b) in flow-through mode (flow rate = 2 mL/min; initial chlorine = 2 ppm as Cl
2
; CNTs = 9 mg; phosphate buffer = 100 mM; error bars represent the standard deviations from at least two experimental results).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
This study demonstrated the simultaneous dechlorination and advanced organic oxidation using electrochemically assisted CNT membranes. The major findings of this study include:
•CNTs in a membrane platform effectively removed chlorine from the feed water during filtration.
•The CNT/chlorine system was capable of producing reactive species to degrade BA through the reductive reaction of chlorine on CNTs, as evidenced by the CV curves and the production of 4-HBA.
•When CNT membranes were used as cathodes, they successfully prevented the saturation of CNTs by chlorine during chlorine removal from water, while also effectively reducing chlorine concentrations in the permeate. This suggests that cathodic currents both regenerate CNT active sites and enhance chlorine removal, thereby increasing the chlorine removal efficiency.
•In the presence of chlorine, electrochemically assisted CNT membranes can oxidize organic molecules by producing reactive species through the catalytic activation of chlorine, demonstrating surface-mediated advanced organic oxidation.
•Electrochemically assisted CNT membranes could be used as an alternative pretreatment method for RO, by regeneratively dechlorinating RO feed waters.

Biofouling in reverse osmosis membranes for seawater desalination: Phenomena and prevention
Matin, Asif; Khan, Z.; Zaidi, S. M. J.; Boyce, M. C.

A review. Reverse osmosis membranes are becoming increasingly popular for water purifn. applications that require high salt rejection such as brackish and seawater desalination. However, due to fouling by microorganisms, they were unable to realize their full potential as of yet. Biofouling leads to the use of higher operating pressure, more frequent chem. cleaning, and shorter membrane life. This paper reviews the causes, consequences and control of biofouling in RO membranes used for seawater desalination. After a brief introduction, the fundamentals of biofouling are discussed in some detail: biofilm formation, role of EPS, and sequence of events leading to biofouling. This is followed by a section on consequences of biofouling on membrane processes with particular emphasis on water permeability and salt rejection. The mechanisms of performance degrdn. are discussed in some detail for both of these parameters. The last section of this paper reviews the different antifouling strategies that have recently gained more attention with special emphasis on membrane surface modification. A brief conclusion with some recommendations and suggestions is presented at the end of the article.

A review, with 9 refs., is given. This paper examines the causes and effects of obstinate biofilms in membrane elements. In these cases problems of increased differential pressure have proven difficult to correct during routine cleaning cycles. Consequently, regrowth rates, as indicated by this differential pressure for such biofilms have been rapid. Exptl. data has been taken from more than a hundred membrane autopsies from around the world. These autopsies have been undertaken when such problematic biofilms are encountered. These confirm that biofilms formed in process and membrane systems are comparable except that membrane biofilms contain greater nos. of fungi. Some operating systems have reported the cessation of chlorination with a significant redn. of biofouling. The paper considers possible causes for this. It also considers the increasing use of proprietary non-oxidizing microbiocides. Conclusions are that biofouling is endemic within membrane systems, yet many systems operate satisfactorily even with a biofilm. Foulant layers can be conditioned or hardened by the repeated use of cleaning programs and there is a strong case for alternating cleaners and biocides as used by the cooling water treatment industry.

A review is given. Biofouling due to microbial growth on the RO membrane adds significant osmotic pressure and causes frequent chem. cleaning which reduces the life of RO membrane. Biocides such as Cl, O3, and UV have been used to control microbial growth correlated to the biol. fouling of the RO membrane. Among them, free Cl is most frequently used but incorporated into membrane damage, disinfection byproduct formation, and microorganism out-growth because of the following quenching process using Na bisulfite. Bromate, formed during ozonization of Br--rich saline water, is classified as a carcinogen by US EPA and WHO and could limit the usage of treated water as drinking water. UV treatment, however, is gaining its popularity since it does not produce any byproduct, quenches remaining chlorine without using sodium bisulfite, and oxidizes org. matter in the saline water. Regardless of its advantages, it has a scaling issue on the quartz sleeve. Therefore, careful comparisons of the biocides are required for SWRO pretreatment. The purpose of this paper is to summarize current disinfection practice for SWRO pretreatment to help plant designers to choose an optimal disinfection pretreatment process.

A review. Biofouling is a crit. issue in membrane H2O and wastewater treatment as it greatly compromises the efficiency of the treatment processes. It is difficult to control and significant economic resources have been dedicated to the development of effective biofouling monitoring and control strategies. This paper highlights the underlying causes of membrane biofouling and provides a review on recent developments of potential monitoring and control methods in H2O and wastewater treatment with the aim of identifying the remaining issues and challenges in this area.

Powell, Joshua; Luh, Jeanne; Coronell, Orlando

The vol.-averaged amide link scission in the arom. polyamide active layer of a reverse osmosis membrane upon exposure to free Cl was quantified at a variety of free Cl exposure times, concns., and pH and rinsing conditions. The results showed that (1) hydroxyl ions are needed for scission to occur, (2) hydroxide-induced amide link scission is a strong function of exposure to hypochlorous acid, (3) the ratio between amide links broken and Cl atoms taken up increased with the chlorination pH and reached a max. of ∼25%, (4) polyamide disintegration occurs when high free Cl concns., alk. conditions, and high exposure times are combined, (5) amide link scission promotes further Cl uptake, and (6) scission at the membrane surface is unrepresentative of vol.-averaged scission in the active layer. Our observations are consistent with previously proposed mechanisms describing amide link scission as a result of the hydrolysis of the N-chlorinated amidic N-C bond due to nucleophilic attack by hydroxyl ions. This study increases the understanding of the physicochem. changes that could occur for membranes in treatment plants using Cl as an upstream disinfectant and the extent and rate at which those changes would occur.

In this work the effect of chlorination on the change of hydrogen bonding behavior and performance of crosslinked arom. polyamide membrane was systematically studied. Chlorination replaced hydrogen with chlorine on the amide group of the membrane polymer and caused the loss of hydrogen bonding sites, confirmed by the systematic shift of the amide I band (C=O stretching vibration) to the higher wavenumbers and the disappearance of the amide II band (N-H bending vibration) by FT-IR spectrum anal. Performance expts. demonstrated that the change of hydrogen bonding behavior due to the chlorination caused the change of flexibility of polymer chains followed by the change of initial flux and subsequent flux change with filtration time.

A serious limitation of most com. polyamide reverse osmosis (RO) membranes is their sensitivity to chlorine attack. By studying the hypochlorite degrdn. of arom. polyamide RO membrane, this work was to get some understandings in the prevention of membrane depreciation and develop membranes with improved chlorine resistance. Membrane performances, including water flux and salt rejection, were evaluated before and after hypochlorite exposure under different pH and concn. conditions. The results showed that chlorination destroyed hydrogen bonds in polyamide chains, causing a notable decline of membrane flux esp. in acid environment; however, membrane performance was slightly improved after the treatment of alk. hypochlorite soln. for a certain time, which was probably due to the effect of amine groups in barrier layer. Based on the attenuated total reflectance Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) characterizations and performance measurements, the results indicated that N-chlorination reaction of arom. polyamide was also reversible, in other words, the N-chlorinated intermediate could be regenerated to initial amide with the alk. treatment before ring-chlorination reaction. This conclusion provided several relative suggestions for membrane cleaning procedures. Finally, a method adopting surface coating was proposed to develop membranes with good chlorine resistance, and the preliminary results showed its potential for applications.

Inorg. and org. chloramines pose a threat to aquatic ecosystems that are exposed to discharges of treated and disinfected wastewater. Conventionally practiced dechlorination with sulfite reduces the most refractory org. chloramines too slowly to produce wastewater effluents that meet current ecosystem protection criteria in the US (i.e. total residual Cl ≤0.011 mg Cl/L in freshwaters). Seeking faster dechlorinating agents, we have measured the rates that 4 test chloramines (NH2Cl, N-Cl-piperidine, N-Cl-leucylalanine and N-Cl-alanylalanine) react with 10 selected reducing agents at pH 7.4 and 8.4. The aq.-phase reducing agents that offer speed advantages over sulfite alone include dithionite, thiosulfate, and iodide-mediated sulfite. Ascorbic acid was the most reactive of the S-free agents but it was slow relative to sulfite. The potential BOD might constrain the choice of aq. reductants. Metallic Fe is shown to reduce inorg. and org. chloramines effectively. The implications of these results for wastewater Cl redn. and anal. are discussed.

Review on strategies for biofouling mitigation in spiral wound membrane systems
Bucs, Szilard S.; Farhat, Nadia; Kruithof, Joop C.; Picioreanu, Cristian; van Loosdrecht, Mark C. M.; Vrouwenvelder, Johannes S.

Because of the uneven distribution of fresh water in time and space, a large no. of regions are experiencing water scarcity and stress. Membrane based desalination technologies have the potential to solve the fresh water crisis in coastal areas. However, in many cases membrane performance is restricted by biofouling. The objective of this review is to provide an overview on the state of the art strategies to control biofouling in spiral wound reverse osmosis membrane systems and point to possible future research directions. A crit. review on biofouling control strategies such as feed water pre-treatment, membrane surface modification, feed spacer geometry optimization and hydrodynamics in spiral wound membrane systems is presented. In conclusion, biofouling cannot be avoided in the long run, and thus biofouling control strategies should focus on delaying the biofilm formation, reducing its impact on membrane performance and enhancing biofilm removal by advanced cleaning strategies. Therefore, future studies should aim on: (i) biofilm structural characterization; (ii) understanding to what extent biofilm properties affect membrane filtration performance, and (iii) developing methods to engineer biofilm properties such that biofouling would have only a low or delayed impact on the filtration process and accumulated biomass can be easily removed.

Pipelines transporting brackish subsurface water, used in the prodn. of bitumen by steam-assisted gravity drainage, are subject to frequent corrosion failures despite the addn. of the oxygen scavenger sodium bisulfite (SBS). Pyrosequencing of 16S rRNA genes was used to det. the microbial community compn. for planktonic samples of transported water and for sessile samples of pipe-assocd. solids (PAS) scraped from pipeline cutouts representing corrosion failures. These were obtained from upstream (PAS-616P) and downstream (PAS-821TP and PAS-821LP, collected under rapid-flow and stagnant conditions, resp.) of the SBS injection point. Most transported water samples had a large fraction (1.8% to 97% of pyrosequencing reads) of Pseudomonas not found in sessile pipe samples. The sessile population of PAS-616P had methanogens (Methanobacteriaceae) as the main (56%) community component, whereas Deltaproteobacteria of the genera Desulfomicrobium and Desulfocapsa were not detected. In contrast, PAS-821TP and PAS-821LP had lower fractions (41% and 0.6%) of Methanobacteriaceae archaea but increased fractions of sulfate-reducing Desulfomicrobium (18% and 48%) and of bisulfite-disproportionating Desulfocapsa (35% and 22%) bacteria. Hence, SBS injection strongly changed the sessile microbial community populations. X-ray diffraction anal. of pipeline scale indicated that iron carbonate was present both upstream and downstream, whereas iron sulfide and sulfur were found only downstream of the SBS injection point, suggesting a contribution of the bisulfite-disproportionating and sulfate-reducing bacteria in the scale to iron corrosion. Incubation of iron coupons with pipeline waters indicated iron corrosion coupled to the formation of methane. Hence, both methanogenic and sulfidogenic microbial communities contributed to corrosion of pipelines transporting these brackish waters. Sequence data are deposited in GenBank with accession no. SRP005237.

Biofilm formation on membrane surfaces causes many operational problems such as a decrease in permeate flux and an increase in hydraulic resistance. In this study, the ability of bacteria to pass through microfiltration (MF) membranes and the growth potential of microfilterable bacteria were investigated in order to understand biofouling in MF-reverse osmosis (RO) integrated membrane systems. Growth of microfilterable bacteria in MF permeate was obsd., indicating that not all MF membranes can guarantee the total rejection of bacteria. Changes in natural org. matter (NOM) characteristics and growth potential of bacteria during the treatment process are important factors in the occurrence of biofilm development in water treatment systems. Anal. of protein-like and humic-like substances in NOM of two successive RO stages revealed an increase in the concns. of both biopolymers and humic substances of RO concs. Unexpectedly, the use of antiscalants was seen to enhance the growth of bacteria in the RO feed water in this study. Bacterial 16s rRNA pyrosequencing revealed that passing source water through the MF membranes dramatically changed bacterial community structure. The bacterial communities that passed through the MF steps primarily belonged to the family Comamonadaceae. However, several bacteria groups including Flavobacteriaceae, Sphingobacteriaceae and Sphingomonadaceae selectively composed the biofilm community formed on the RO membranes. Thus, understanding the selectivity and filterability of MF towards microorganisms involved in biofouling on RO membrane surfaces is crucial for the improvement of membrane-related operational processes.

Biological control of microbial attachment: a promising alternative for mitigating membrane biofouling
Xiong, Yanghui; Liu, Yu

Microbial attachment to a solid surface is a universal phenomenon occurring in both natural and engineering systems and is responsible for various types of biofouling. Membrane systems have been widely applied in drinking water prodn., wastewater reuse, and seawater desalination. However, membrane biofouling is the bottleneck that limits the development of membrane systems. In this review, some biol. control strategies of microbial attachment which would have great potential in alleviating membrane biofouling are discussed, including inhibition of quorum sensing system, nitric oxide-induced biofilm dispersal, enzymic disruption of extracellular polysaccharides, proteins, and DNA, inhibition of microbial attachment by energy uncoupling, use of cell wall hydrolases, and disruption of biofilm by bacteriophage. It appears that biol. control of microbial attachment would be a novel and promising alternative for mitigating membrane biofouling and would be a new research niche that deserves further study.

Reverse osmosis (RO) membrane systems are widely used in water purifn. plants. Redn. in plant performance due to biofilm formation over the membrane is an inherent problem. As quorum sensing (QS) mechanisms of microorganisms have been reported to be involved in the formation of biofilm, ways are sought for quorum quenching (QQ) and thereby prevention of biofilm formation. In this study using a chemostat culture run for seven days in a CDC reactor it was found that a natural QQ compd., vanillin considerably suppressed bacterial biofilm formation on RO membrane. There was 97% redn. in biofilm surface coverage, when grown in the presence of vanillin. Similarly, the av. thickness, total biomass and the total protein content of the biofilm that formed in the presence of vanillin were significantly less than that of the control. However vanillin had no effect on 1-day old pre-formed biofilm.

Quorum quenching, enzymic quenching of bacterial quorum sensing, has recently proven its potential as a novel approach of biofouling control in the membrane bioreactor (MBR) for advanced wastewater treatment. However, the short catalytic lifetime and difficulty in recovering free enzyme hamper the successful application of the quorum quenching technique in the MBR under a long-term continuous operation. In this study, a magnetic enzyme carrier (MEC) was prepd. by immobilizing the quorum quenching enzyme (acylase) on magnetic particles to overcome the tech. limitations of free enzyme. The MEC showed no activity decrease under both continuous shaking for 14 days and 29 iterative cycles of reuse. Furthermore, the comparison of the MEC with free enzyme in a batch type MBR showed that the MEC efficiently alleviated the membrane biofouling and showed a great advantage over free enzyme in terms of recycled use and stability in mixed liquor. When the MEC was applied to the lab scale MBR in a continuous operation, it also enhanced the membrane permeability to a large extent compared with a conventional MBR with no enzyme.

Chlorine-resistant polyimide thin film composite (TFC) RO membranes were prepd. via interfacial polymn. of m-phenylene diamine (MPD) and 1,2,4,5-benzene tetracarbonyl chloride (BTC) and subsequent thermal imidization. The effects of annealing on the membranes performance were investigated. Increasing temp. and duration during the thermal treatment accelerated the imidization of the poly(amic acid) membranes and converted their amorphous structures to semi-cryst. structures, deteriorating their performance. The addn. of a crosslinking agent, trimesoyl chloride (TMC), during the interfacial polymn. improved the membrane's performance. The polyimide thin film composite, reverse osmosis membranes prepd. from MPD, BTC and TMC showed significantly enhanced chlorine resistance due to the elimination of chlorine-sensitive sites by the replacement of amide linkage with imide linkage.

A novel random terpolymer poly(methylacryloxyethyldimethyl benzyl ammonium chloride-r-acrylamide-r-2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate) (P(MDBAC-r-Am-r-HEMA)) was synthesized via free radical polymn. and used as the coating material on the polyamide thin film composite (TFC) reverse osmosis (RO) membrane to improve its chlorine resistance and antifouling performance. The chlorine resistance of the membranes was evaluated by cross-flow filtration of the NaClO soln. Antifouling performance was evaluated by cross-flow filtration of the protein soln. and cell-culture expts. The membrane surface was analyzed via ATR-FTIR, XPS, SEM and streaming potential measurements. The coated membrane can tolerate chlorine exposure over 16,000 ppm h, which is 7-10 times the pristine membrane. The bacteria growth can be significantly depressed on the coated membrane surface. The coated membrane can retain its flux very well under protein filtration. It is believed that the surface coating layer works as a protective and sacrificial layer, preventing the attack of chlorine on the underlying polyamide film. The PMDBAC and PAm components are essential to the antimicrobial property and the improved surface hydrophilicity is beneficial to the antifouling performance of the membrane. The coated membrane offers potential use as a novel RO membrane with improved antifouling performance and chlorine resistance.

High-performance chlorine-resistant thin-film composite (TFC) membranes with zwitterions were fabricated by in situ surface modification of polyamide with 2,6-diaminopyridine and the subsequential quaternization with 3-bromopropionic acid. The successful modification of the TFC polyamide surface with zwitterions was confirmed by various characterizations including surface chem., surface hydrophilicity, and surface charge. The transport performance of the membrane was measured in both of the cross-flow reverse osmosis (RO) and forward osmosis processes, and the results showed that the modified TFC membrane improved both of its water permeability and permselectivity with the increased A and A/B ratios upon modification with zwitterions. A chlorination mechanism study illustrated that the modified membrane with zwitterions could prevent the Orton rearrangement of the benzene ring of the polyamide layer. Importantly and excitingly, the optimal chlorinated TFC membrane with zwitterions achieved a very high water flux of 72.15 ± 2.55 LMH with 99.67 ± 0.09% of salt rejection in the cross-flow RO process under 15 bar.

The UV/free chlorine process forms reactive species such as hydroxyl radicals (HO•), chlorine atoms (Cl•), Cl2•-, and O•-. The specific roles of these reactive species in aq. micropollutant degrdn. in the UV/chlorine process under different conditions were investigated using a steady-state kinetic model. Benzoic acid (BA) was chosen as the model micropollutant. The steady-state kinetic model developed fitted the exptl. data well. The results showed that HO• and Cl• contributed substantially to BA degrdn., while the roles of the other reactive species such as Cl2•-and O•- were negligible. The overall degrdn. rate of BA decreased as the pH increased from 6 to 9. In particular, the relative contributions of HO• and Cl• to the degrdn. changed from 34.7% and 65.3% resp. at pH 6 to 37.9% and 62% resp. at pH 9 under the conditions evaluated. Their relative contributions also changed slightly with variations in chlorine dosage, BA concn. and chloride concn. The scavenging effect of natural org. matter (NOM) on Cl• was relatively small compared to that on HO•, while bicarbonate preferentially reduced the contribution of Cl•. This study is the first to demonstrate the contributions of different reactive species to the micropollutant degrdn. in the UV/chlorine system under environmentally relevant conditions.

In this work, the degrdn. of atrazine by the combination of UV and chlorine (UV/chlorine) due to the formation of radicals during chlorine photolysis was systematically investigated in terms of efficiency, factors that influence the degrdn. kinetics, as well as oxidn. products. It was found that the degrdn. efficiency of atrazine was enhanced by UV/chlorine compared to UV or chlorine alone. The degrdn. efficiency of atrazine was favorable at a lower pH, but was inhibited in the presence of natural org. matters. Meanwhile, the initial chlorine dosage, alky., and chloride barely influenced the degrdn. efficiency under neutral pH conditions. The degrdn. of atrazine by UV/chlorine was inhibited in real waters (i.e., surface water and ground water) compared to in deionized water but was still more effective than UV alone. The oxidn. products of atrazine resulting from de-alkylation, dechlorination-hydroxylation, alkylic-hydroxylation, alkylic-oxidn., alkylic-hydroxylation-dehydration, deamination-hydroxylation, and dechlorination-hydrogenation in UV/chlorine process were detected, which were slightly different from those formed in UV/H2O2 (commonly used UV-based advanced oxidn. process). Particularly, the yields of three primary transformation products (desethyl-atrazine (DEA), desisopropyl-atrazine (DIA), and desethyl-desisopropyl-atrazine (DEIA)) were comparatively quantified in these two processes. The different trend of them formed in UV/chlorine system (DEA:DIA≈4) compared to that formed in UV/H2O2 system (DEA:DIA≈1) could be ascribed to the different reaction reactivities and mechanisms between HO• and Cl• with atrazine.

A variety of dimensional-structured nanocarbons were applied for the first time as metal-free catalysts to activate persulfate (PS) for catalytic oxidn. of phenolics and dyes as well as their degrdn. intermediates. Single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs), reduced graphene oxide (rGO), and mesoporous carbon (CMK-8) demonstrated superior catalytic activities for heterogeneous PS activation, whereas fullerene (C60), nanodiamonds, and graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) presented low efficiencies. Moreover, the carbocatalysts presented even better catalytic performances than activated carbon and metal oxides, such as Fe3O4, CuO, Co3O4, and MnO2. The activity of prepd. rGO-900 was further competing to the most efficient electron donor of zerovalent iron (ZVI). Both characterization and oxidn. results suggested that the catalytic performances of the nanocarbons are detd. by the intrinsic atom arrangements of carbon hybridization, pore structure, defective sites, and functional groups (esp. the carbonyl groups). ESR (EPR) spectra revealed that carbocatalysts might act as an excellent electron bridge in activation of PS to oxidize adsorbed water directly to generate hydroxyl radicals, distinct from homogeneous and metal-based catalytic activation. This study discovers several efficient nanocarbons for heterogeneous PS activation, and it presents new insights into the catalytic activation processes, providing a fascinating strategy to develop metal-free catalysts for green remediation.

C nanotubes (CNTs) have been found to activate persulfates (i.e., peroxymonosulfate and peroxydisulfate) into reactive species that are capable of oxidizing orgs. in water. In the presence of single- or multi-walled CNTs, persulfates effectively degraded phenolic compds. and certain pharmaceuticals. phenol derivs. substituted with electron-withdrawing groups, such as benzoic acid and nitrobenzene, were resistant to degrdn. by the CNT/persulfate system. Based on observations regarding persulfate decompn. and linear sweep voltammetry using a CNT electrode, it has been suggested that persulfates bind onto the surface of CNTs, forming reactive complexes that are immediately decompd. upon reaction with org. compds. ESR spectroscopy with spin-trapping indicates that these reactive species are distinct from sulfate radical anions or hydroxyl radicals. The CNT-activated persulfate system shows promise as a novel treatment technol. for the selective oxidn. of org. contaminants in water.

We explored factors influencing hydroxyl radical (•OH) formation during ozonation of multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) and assessed this system's viability as a next-generation advanced oxidn. process (AOP). Using std. reactivity metrics for ozone-based AOPs (RCT values), MWCNTs promoted •OH formation during ozonation to levels exceeding ozone (both alone and with activated carbon) and equiv. to ozone with hydrogen peroxide. MWCNTs oxidized with nitric acid exhibited vastly greater rates of ozone consumption and •OH formation relative to as-received MWCNTs. While some of this enhancement reflects their greater suspension stability, a strong correlation between RCT values and surface oxygen concns. from XPS suggests that surface sites generated during MWCNT oxidn. promote •OH exposure. Removal of several ozone-recalcitrant species [para-chlorobenzoic acid (p-CBA), atrazine, DEET, and ibuprofen] was not significantly inhibited in the presence of radical scavengers (humic acid, carbonate), in complex aquatic matrixes (Iowa River water) and after 12 h of continuous exposure of MWCNTs to concd. ozone solns. As a proof-of-concept, oxidized MWCNTs deposited on a ceramic membrane chem. oxidized p-CBA in a flow through system, with removal increasing with influent ozone concn. and mass of deposited MWCNTs (in mg/cm2). This hybrid membrane platform, which integrates adsorption, oxidn., and filtration via an immobilized MWCNT layer, may serve as the basis for future novel nanomaterial-enabled technologies, although long-term performance trials under representative treatment scenarios remain necessary.

In Situ Electrochemical Generation of Reactive Chlorine Species for Efficient Ultrafiltration Membrane Self-Cleaning
Wang, Xiaoxiong; Sun, Meng; Zhao, Yumeng; Wang, Chi; Ma, Wen; Wong, Michael S.; Elimelech, Menachem

Reactive membranes based on hydroxyl radical generation are hindered by the need for chem. dosing and complicated module and material design. Herein, we use an electrochem. approach featuring in situ generation of reactive (radical) Cl species (RCS) through anodization of chloride ions for membrane self-cleaning. A hybridized C nanotube (CNT)-functionalized ceramic membrane (h-CNT/CM), possessing high hydrophilicity, permeability, and cond., was fabricated. Using carbamazepine (CBZ) as a probe, we confirmed the presence of RCS in the electrified h-CNT/CM. The rapid and complete degrdn. of CBZ in a single-pass ultrafiltration indicates a high localized RCS concn. within the 3-dimensional porous CNT interwoven layer. We further demonstrate that the electrogeneration of RCS is a crit. prestep for free Cl (HClO and ClO-) formation. The self-cleaning efficiency of the membrane after fouling with a model org. foulant (alginate) was assessed using an electrified cross-flow membrane filtration system. The fouled h-CNT/CM exhibits a near complete H2O flux recovery following a short (1 min) self-cleaning with an applied voltage of 3 or 4 V and feed solns. of 100 or 10 mM NaCl, resp. Considering the superior performance of the RCS-mediated self-cleaning compared to conventional membrane chem. cleaning using Na hypochlorite, the results exemplify an effective strategy for in situ electrogeneration of RCS to achieve a highly efficient membrane self-cleaning.

Elec. conductive polymeric ultrafiltration membranes were fabricated by pressure filtering a thin layer of poly(vinyl alc.) - crosslinked with carboxylated multiwalled carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and succinic acid - onto a support membrane. The effect of the degree of crosslinking and that of CNT concn. on the performance of these membranes was evaluated. These membranes demonstrated high pure water flux with good particle sepn., high elec. cond., low polymer crystallinity, and low surface tensions. Membranes formed with 20 min crosslinking curing times and 20 w/% CNT concn. showed elec. resistivity as low as 2.8 × 10-4 Ω m (conductivities as high as 3.6 × 103 S/m), pure water flux of 1440 L/m2 h at pressures of 550 kPa, and triple-point initial contact angles as low as 40° with high hysteresis.

Hypochlorite oxidn. of NO2- does not take place by O atom transfer, but proceeds by Cl+ transfer from HOCl to NO2- to give NO2Cl as a reaction intermediate. The kinetics indicate that the subsequent decompn. of NO2Cl proceeds by 2 pathways: loss of Cl- to give NO2+ and reaction of NO2Cl with NO2- to form N2O4 and Cl-. At high Cl- and low OH- and NO21 concns. the overall rate of NO3- formation is suppressed by Cl-. The relative reactivities for the reaction with NO2+ are Oh- » Cl- » H2O. Although O isotope expts. are consistent with a Cl+ transfer mechanism, the rate of exchange of O between OCl- and H2O is relatively rapid (even at high pH in the absence of Cl-). The OCl-/H2O exchange rate in base is predicted to be independent of OH- concn.

Overall apparent reaction rates for the removal of monochloramine (MCA) in granular activated carbon (GAC) beds were detd. using a fixed-bed reactor system and under conditions typical for swimming pool water treatment. Reaction rates dropped and quasi-stationary conditions were reached quickly. Diffusional mass transport in the pores was shown to be limiting the overall reaction rate. This was reflected consistently in the Thiele modulus, in the effect of temp., pore size distribution and of grain size on the reaction rates. Pores <2.5 times the diam. of the monochloramine mol. were shown to be barely accessible for the monochloramine conversion reaction. GACs with a significant proportion of large mesopores were found to have the highest overall reactivity for monochloramine removal.

A review. Reverse osmosis membranes are becoming increasingly popular for water purifn. applications that require high salt rejection such as brackish and seawater desalination. However, due to fouling by microorganisms, they were unable to realize their full potential as of yet. Biofouling leads to the use of higher operating pressure, more frequent chem. cleaning, and shorter membrane life. This paper reviews the causes, consequences and control of biofouling in RO membranes used for seawater desalination. After a brief introduction, the fundamentals of biofouling are discussed in some detail: biofilm formation, role of EPS, and sequence of events leading to biofouling. This is followed by a section on consequences of biofouling on membrane processes with particular emphasis on water permeability and salt rejection. The mechanisms of performance degrdn. are discussed in some detail for both of these parameters. The last section of this paper reviews the different antifouling strategies that have recently gained more attention with special emphasis on membrane surface modification. A brief conclusion with some recommendations and suggestions is presented at the end of the article.

A review, with 9 refs., is given. This paper examines the causes and effects of obstinate biofilms in membrane elements. In these cases problems of increased differential pressure have proven difficult to correct during routine cleaning cycles. Consequently, regrowth rates, as indicated by this differential pressure for such biofilms have been rapid. Exptl. data has been taken from more than a hundred membrane autopsies from around the world. These autopsies have been undertaken when such problematic biofilms are encountered. These confirm that biofilms formed in process and membrane systems are comparable except that membrane biofilms contain greater nos. of fungi. Some operating systems have reported the cessation of chlorination with a significant redn. of biofouling. The paper considers possible causes for this. It also considers the increasing use of proprietary non-oxidizing microbiocides. Conclusions are that biofouling is endemic within membrane systems, yet many systems operate satisfactorily even with a biofilm. Foulant layers can be conditioned or hardened by the repeated use of cleaning programs and there is a strong case for alternating cleaners and biocides as used by the cooling water treatment industry.

A review is given. Biofouling due to microbial growth on the RO membrane adds significant osmotic pressure and causes frequent chem. cleaning which reduces the life of RO membrane. Biocides such as Cl, O3, and UV have been used to control microbial growth correlated to the biol. fouling of the RO membrane. Among them, free Cl is most frequently used but incorporated into membrane damage, disinfection byproduct formation, and microorganism out-growth because of the following quenching process using Na bisulfite. Bromate, formed during ozonization of Br--rich saline water, is classified as a carcinogen by US EPA and WHO and could limit the usage of treated water as drinking water. UV treatment, however, is gaining its popularity since it does not produce any byproduct, quenches remaining chlorine without using sodium bisulfite, and oxidizes org. matter in the saline water. Regardless of its advantages, it has a scaling issue on the quartz sleeve. Therefore, careful comparisons of the biocides are required for SWRO pretreatment. The purpose of this paper is to summarize current disinfection practice for SWRO pretreatment to help plant designers to choose an optimal disinfection pretreatment process.

The vol.-averaged amide link scission in the arom. polyamide active layer of a reverse osmosis membrane upon exposure to free Cl was quantified at a variety of free Cl exposure times, concns., and pH and rinsing conditions. The results showed that (1) hydroxyl ions are needed for scission to occur, (2) hydroxide-induced amide link scission is a strong function of exposure to hypochlorous acid, (3) the ratio between amide links broken and Cl atoms taken up increased with the chlorination pH and reached a max. of ∼25%, (4) polyamide disintegration occurs when high free Cl concns., alk. conditions, and high exposure times are combined, (5) amide link scission promotes further Cl uptake, and (6) scission at the membrane surface is unrepresentative of vol.-averaged scission in the active layer. Our observations are consistent with previously proposed mechanisms describing amide link scission as a result of the hydrolysis of the N-chlorinated amidic N-C bond due to nucleophilic attack by hydroxyl ions. This study increases the understanding of the physicochem. changes that could occur for membranes in treatment plants using Cl as an upstream disinfectant and the extent and rate at which those changes would occur.

In this work the effect of chlorination on the change of hydrogen bonding behavior and performance of crosslinked arom. polyamide membrane was systematically studied. Chlorination replaced hydrogen with chlorine on the amide group of the membrane polymer and caused the loss of hydrogen bonding sites, confirmed by the systematic shift of the amide I band (C=O stretching vibration) to the higher wavenumbers and the disappearance of the amide II band (N-H bending vibration) by FT-IR spectrum anal. Performance expts. demonstrated that the change of hydrogen bonding behavior due to the chlorination caused the change of flexibility of polymer chains followed by the change of initial flux and subsequent flux change with filtration time.

A serious limitation of most com. polyamide reverse osmosis (RO) membranes is their sensitivity to chlorine attack. By studying the hypochlorite degrdn. of arom. polyamide RO membrane, this work was to get some understandings in the prevention of membrane depreciation and develop membranes with improved chlorine resistance. Membrane performances, including water flux and salt rejection, were evaluated before and after hypochlorite exposure under different pH and concn. conditions. The results showed that chlorination destroyed hydrogen bonds in polyamide chains, causing a notable decline of membrane flux esp. in acid environment; however, membrane performance was slightly improved after the treatment of alk. hypochlorite soln. for a certain time, which was probably due to the effect of amine groups in barrier layer. Based on the attenuated total reflectance Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) characterizations and performance measurements, the results indicated that N-chlorination reaction of arom. polyamide was also reversible, in other words, the N-chlorinated intermediate could be regenerated to initial amide with the alk. treatment before ring-chlorination reaction. This conclusion provided several relative suggestions for membrane cleaning procedures. Finally, a method adopting surface coating was proposed to develop membranes with good chlorine resistance, and the preliminary results showed its potential for applications.

Inorg. and org. chloramines pose a threat to aquatic ecosystems that are exposed to discharges of treated and disinfected wastewater. Conventionally practiced dechlorination with sulfite reduces the most refractory org. chloramines too slowly to produce wastewater effluents that meet current ecosystem protection criteria in the US (i.e. total residual Cl ≤0.011 mg Cl/L in freshwaters). Seeking faster dechlorinating agents, we have measured the rates that 4 test chloramines (NH2Cl, N-Cl-piperidine, N-Cl-leucylalanine and N-Cl-alanylalanine) react with 10 selected reducing agents at pH 7.4 and 8.4. The aq.-phase reducing agents that offer speed advantages over sulfite alone include dithionite, thiosulfate, and iodide-mediated sulfite. Ascorbic acid was the most reactive of the S-free agents but it was slow relative to sulfite. The potential BOD might constrain the choice of aq. reductants. Metallic Fe is shown to reduce inorg. and org. chloramines effectively. The implications of these results for wastewater Cl redn. and anal. are discussed.

Because of the uneven distribution of fresh water in time and space, a large no. of regions are experiencing water scarcity and stress. Membrane based desalination technologies have the potential to solve the fresh water crisis in coastal areas. However, in many cases membrane performance is restricted by biofouling. The objective of this review is to provide an overview on the state of the art strategies to control biofouling in spiral wound reverse osmosis membrane systems and point to possible future research directions. A crit. review on biofouling control strategies such as feed water pre-treatment, membrane surface modification, feed spacer geometry optimization and hydrodynamics in spiral wound membrane systems is presented. In conclusion, biofouling cannot be avoided in the long run, and thus biofouling control strategies should focus on delaying the biofilm formation, reducing its impact on membrane performance and enhancing biofilm removal by advanced cleaning strategies. Therefore, future studies should aim on: (i) biofilm structural characterization; (ii) understanding to what extent biofilm properties affect membrane filtration performance, and (iii) developing methods to engineer biofilm properties such that biofouling would have only a low or delayed impact on the filtration process and accumulated biomass can be easily removed.

Pipelines transporting brackish subsurface water, used in the prodn. of bitumen by steam-assisted gravity drainage, are subject to frequent corrosion failures despite the addn. of the oxygen scavenger sodium bisulfite (SBS). Pyrosequencing of 16S rRNA genes was used to det. the microbial community compn. for planktonic samples of transported water and for sessile samples of pipe-assocd. solids (PAS) scraped from pipeline cutouts representing corrosion failures. These were obtained from upstream (PAS-616P) and downstream (PAS-821TP and PAS-821LP, collected under rapid-flow and stagnant conditions, resp.) of the SBS injection point. Most transported water samples had a large fraction (1.8% to 97% of pyrosequencing reads) of Pseudomonas not found in sessile pipe samples. The sessile population of PAS-616P had methanogens (Methanobacteriaceae) as the main (56%) community component, whereas Deltaproteobacteria of the genera Desulfomicrobium and Desulfocapsa were not detected. In contrast, PAS-821TP and PAS-821LP had lower fractions (41% and 0.6%) of Methanobacteriaceae archaea but increased fractions of sulfate-reducing Desulfomicrobium (18% and 48%) and of bisulfite-disproportionating Desulfocapsa (35% and 22%) bacteria. Hence, SBS injection strongly changed the sessile microbial community populations. X-ray diffraction anal. of pipeline scale indicated that iron carbonate was present both upstream and downstream, whereas iron sulfide and sulfur were found only downstream of the SBS injection point, suggesting a contribution of the bisulfite-disproportionating and sulfate-reducing bacteria in the scale to iron corrosion. Incubation of iron coupons with pipeline waters indicated iron corrosion coupled to the formation of methane. Hence, both methanogenic and sulfidogenic microbial communities contributed to corrosion of pipelines transporting these brackish waters. Sequence data are deposited in GenBank with accession no. SRP005237.
